One of the most notable controversies the New York Times Magazine faced in recent years was the publication of an opinion essay by Senator Tom Cotton in June 2020. In the essay, Cotton called for the use of military force to quell protests that were taking place across the country in response to the killing of George Floyd. The publication of the article sparked widespread backlash, with many readers and journalists accusing the magazine of normalizing fascist ideas and putting Black lives in danger.

In response to the controversy, the New York Times Magazine initially defended its decision to publish the article, citing its commitment to presenting a diversity of viewpoints. However, the backlash continued to grow, and several staff members publicly condemned the decision to run the piece. Ultimately, the magazine's editor-in-chief, Jake Silverstein, acknowledged that the essay's publication had been a mistake and apologized for the harm that it had caused.

Another controversy the magazine faced in 2019 was related to a cover story about slavery and the legacy of cotton that many readers found offensive. The cover featured an image of a Black woman picking cotton, which some readers said perpetuated racist stereotypes and minimized the violence of slavery. The magazine ultimately apologized for the cover and removed the image from its website.

Overall, in response to controversies and backlash, the New York Times Magazine has generally taken a responsive approach. They have acknowledged mistakes when they've been made, apologized for any harm caused, and taken steps to address the issues raised by readers and staff members.
